content:
🧬 SAMMY-seq: Chromatin State Analysis

Reveal Chromatin Architecture Without Antibodies

SAMMY-seq (Sequential Analysis of MacroMolecules accessibilitY sequencing) is a revolutionary method for genome-wide mapping of chromatin states through sequential extraction of nuclear fractions. This technique separates chromatin by accessibility - from open euchromatin to highly condensed heterochromatin - providing comprehensive insights into chromatin organization.

🔬 What is SAMMY-seq?

SAMMY-seq is a high-throughput sequencing-based method that characterizes chromatin dynamics by sequentially extracting distinct nuclear fractions based on their solubility and accessibility:

📊 Sequential Extraction Fractions

  • S1 Fraction (Soluble): Freely soluble proteins and highly accessible chromatin - enriched in active euchromatin

  • S2 Fraction (DNase-accessible): Chromatin released after DNase treatment - moderately accessible regions

  • S3 Fraction (High-salt extractable): DNase-resistant chromatin extracted with high salt buffer - less accessible regions

  • S4 Fraction (Urea-soluble): Most condensed and insoluble chromatin extracted with urea buffer - highly condensed heterochromatin enriched in lamina-associated domains (LADs)

🎯 Key Advantages

Why Choose SAMMY-seq?

  • 🚫 No Antibodies Required: Unlike ChIP-seq, no expensive or specific antibodies needed

  • 🔗 No Crosslinking: Avoids crosslinking artifacts that can affect other chromatin methods

  • ⚡ Fast & Simple: Straightforward protocol, easy to perform in any molecular biology lab

  • 💰 Cost-Effective: Cheap alternative to multiple ChIP-seq experiments

  • 🧫 Primary Cells Compatible: Works with limited cell numbers, suitable for primary cells

  • 🎯 Robust & Reproducible: Reliable results across different labs and conditions

🔍 What SAMMY-seq Reveals

Chromatin Architecture

  • Heterochromatin Domains: Identify regions of condensed, transcriptionally silent chromatin

  • Euchromatin Regions: Map accessible, transcriptionally active chromatin

  • LADs (Lamina-Associated Domains): S4 fraction enriched in peripheral heterochromatin

  • Chromatin Accessibility Gradient: Continuous spectrum from highly accessible to highly condensed

Nuclear Organization

  • Compartmentalization: Define genome compartments based on biochemical properties

  • Nuclear Periphery: Identify genes associated with nuclear lamina

  • Chromatin Dynamics: Track changes in chromatin state during differentiation or disease

🧪 Scientific Applications

Disease Research

  • Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome: Detect early-stage heterochromatin alterations in progeria fibroblasts

  • Cancer: Identify aberrant chromatin organization in tumor cells

  • Aging: Map age-related changes in heterochromatin structure

  • Neurodegeneration: Study chromatin dysfunction in neurodegenerative diseases

Basic Research

  • Development: Track chromatin remodeling during differentiation

  • Cell Identity: Define cell-type specific chromatin landscapes

  • Epigenetic Regulation: Understand chromatin-based gene regulation

  • Stress Response: Monitor chromatin changes under cellular stress

🔬 Pipeline Analysis Workflow

The nf-core/sammyseq pipeline provides comprehensive analysis:

  1. Quality Control: FastQC assessment of raw sequencing reads

  2. Trimming: Adapter removal and quality filtering

  3. Alignment: Map reads to reference genome (BWA/Bowtie2)

  4. Filtering: Remove duplicates, low-quality reads, blacklisted regions

  5. Normalization: Quantile normalization across fractions

  6. Peak Calling: Identify enriched regions in each fraction

  7. Differential Analysis: Compare chromatin states between conditions

  8. Compartment Calling: Define euchromatin vs heterochromatin compartments

  9. Visualization: Generate BigWig tracks for genome browser

  10. QC Reporting: Comprehensive MultiQC report

📋 Input Requirements

Sample Sheet Format (CSV):

sample,fastq_1,fastq_2,fraction
control_S1,control_S1_R1.fastq.gz,control_S1_R2.fastq.gz,S1
control_S2,control_S2_R1.fastq.gz,control_S2_R2.fastq.gz,S2
control_S3,control_S3_R1.fastq.gz,control_S3_R2.fastq.gz,S3
control_S4,control_S4_R1.fastq.gz,control_S4_R2.fastq.gz,S4
treated_S1,treated_S1_R1.fastq.gz,treated_S1_R2.fastq.gz,S1
treated_S2,treated_S2_R1.fastq.gz,treated_S2_R2.fastq.gz,S2
treated_S3,treated_S3_R1.fastq.gz,treated_S3_R2.fastq.gz,S3
treated_S4,treated_S4_R1.fastq.gz,treated_S4_R2.fastq.gz,S4

Required Columns:

  • sample - Unique sample identifier

  • fastq_1 - Path to R1 FASTQ file (or URL)

  • fastq_2 - Path to R2 FASTQ file for paired-end (optional)

  • fraction - Extraction fraction: S1, S2, S3, or S4

📊 Key Outputs

Alignment & Coverage

  • BAM Files: Aligned reads for each sample/fraction

  • BigWig Tracks: Genome browser visualization files

  • Coverage Plots: Chromatin accessibility profiles

Chromatin State Analysis

  • Enrichment Profiles: Fraction-specific enrichment across genome

  • Compartment Calls: Euchromatin vs heterochromatin domains

  • LAD Predictions: Lamina-associated domains from S4 fraction

  • Differential Regions: Chromatin state changes between conditions

Quality Control

  • MultiQC Report: Comprehensive quality metrics across all samples

  • Fraction Statistics: Read distribution across fractions

  • Correlation Analysis: Sample-to-sample reproducibility

🧬 Reference Genome Selection

Choose from comprehensive reference genomes:

  • 🧑 Human: GRCh37, GRCh38, hg19, hg38

  • 🐭 Mouse: GRCm38, GRCm39, mm10, mm39

  • 🔬 Model Organisms: Zebrafish, fly, C. elegans, yeast

  • 🌱 Plants: Arabidopsis, rice, maize

  • 🐄 Livestock: Cow, pig, horse, chicken

📚 Scientific References

Key Publications:

  • Lucini F, et al. (2024) "Biochemical properties of chromatin domains define genome compartmentalization." Nucleic Acids Research, 52(12)

  • Sebestyén E, et al. (2020) "SAMMY-seq reveals early alteration of heterochromatin and deregulation of bivalent genes in Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome." Nature Communications, 11:6274

💡 Analysis Tips

  • Biological Replicates: Use at least 2-3 replicates per condition for robust statistics

  • All Fractions: Process all four fractions (S1-S4) for complete chromatin landscape

  • Paired-End Recommended: Better mapping quality and fragment size information

  • Sequencing Depth: 20-40M reads per fraction sufficient for genome-wide analysis

Perfect for Research in: Chromatin organization • Heterochromatin dynamics • Nuclear architecture • Lamina-associated domains • Epigenetic regulation • Disease chromatin • Aging • Development • Cell identity • Progeria • Cancer epigenetics
